results.title: Daughters of the dust [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Julie Dash, Geechee Girls Production, WMG and American Playhouse Theatrical Films
results.brief_description: At the turn of the century the Peazant family, a multigenerational community threatened with break-up, gathers for a reunion on an island off the coast of South Carolina, historically a place of entry for the European slave ships and a haven for self-emancipated Africans and indigenous peoples. Structured around the twin narratives of Nana, born into slavery, and that of the Unborn Child, this is a rites-of-passage story invoking Islam, Christianity and West African spiritual customs. It is not narrative-driven in the Western mode but is balletic, operatic, non-linear and based on the African oral tradition of the Griot (story-teller), drawing on the Gullah dialect. Dash was also inspired by the literature of African-American women writers. Cast includes Adisa Anderson, Cora Lee Day, Alva Rogers, Barbara-0 and Trula Hoosier.

results.title: Daughters of darkness = The Promise of red lips = The Red lips = Le Rouge aux levres
results.creator_credit: Harry Kumel, Paul Collet, Henry Lange, Maya Films and Showking Films
results.brief_description: In the lost space of an opulent Ostend hotel, eerily deserted in the off season, a young but hardly innocent couple on their honeymoon encounter the apparently ageless, sunlight-fearing, lesbian Countess Bathory. Kumel imaginatively balances the erotic malaise and violence of vampire folklore and a European (specifically Belgian) surrealist tradition with thirties Hollywood camp and comic strip tableaux. Perverse sexuality is located in a setting of decadent highlife which seems to immobilise the “victims”. Originally titled “La Rogue aux Levres” (Lips of Blood). Cast includes John Karlen, Delphine Seyrig, Danielle Ouimet and Andrea Rau.
results.title_for_label: Daughters of darkness = The Promise of red lips = The Red lips = Le Rouge aux levres

results.title: Date of birth
results.creator_credit: Donald Fraser, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A tribute to the older worker’s high standard of dependability and productivity, and a plea to employers to remove age barriers in hiring new staff. The bitter disappointment felt by an able man denied work because he is over forty-five is expressed in a brief dramatic sequence, and then the film presents the actual record of employees in this age group, reminding us that there is less absenteeism, a lower turnover rate and an equal standard of production among older workers. The importance to the whole country of giving a fair chance to workers over forty-five years of age is explained, and ways in which their problem is being tackled are described.

results.title: Data for decision
results.creator_credit: David Millar, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at the ‘Canada Land Inventory Geo-information System’, a computer system used to help manage and develop Canadian land. Shows the computer’s capacity for storing information, correlating and interpreting facts, and converting data into maps and diagrams. Photographed by Martin Duckworth, Jacques Foges and Kjeld Nielsen; animation by Donald Stearn; edited by Arthur Lipsett; sound by Sidney Pearson and George Croll; narrated by Richard Gilbert.

results.title: Ordinary people
results.creator_credit: Doug Miles and University of Pittsburgh
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the symptoms and dynamics of child abuse showing how relatively normal, average parents with high stress levels and unrealistic child rearing expectations can become abusive parents.

results.title: Crafts in Yackandandah
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inspired by the changing landscape, the availability of raw materials and a sense of community, various talented crafts practitioners call Yackandandah home. From internationally recognised potter John Dermer and local weaver Jan Clements, to Christine Thorpe owner of Spiritus Gallery we are introduced to wood carvers, guitar makers and jewellery designers.

results.title: Brendan Smith : making a difference in Rutherglen
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: A self proclaimed ‘Average Joe’, Brendan Smith offers his insatiable enthusiasm and passion for all things audio visual, installing professional standard lighting and sound equipment in Rutherglen’s local hall, making it possible for everyone in the community to connect with the arts.

results.title: Yackandandah music
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: The future stars of the Australian music industry are alive and well and living in Yackandandah. No matter where life takes them, music is sure to play a big part in the lives of these young musicians. From Richard Perso and The Two Girls to the tiny violinists from ‘Violindigo’ the town of Yackandandah supports its emerging artists by providing them a stage at the Shed during the annual Yack Folk Festival.

results.title: Below Beechworth
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Starting at the Burke Museum, local guide Dan Goonan, gives us a short history lesson about the gold rush days of Beechworth. We then follow Goonan as he takes us on a tour of the hidden underground tunnels which remain as a legacy of the Gold Rush. This film explores what lies below Beechworth, the parts you rarely see.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Indigo
results.brief_description: Nine stories centred around three towns of Indigo Shire in northern Victoria: Yackandandah, Beechworth and Rutherglen. These films cover different aspects of the life of these towns. From local businesses to burning passions, the locals reflect on what they put in and what they get out of these rural centres.
